Notes: An 'e' grapheme with a tail on the bottom left or left side. It is often (but not always) used to represent an alphabeme 'e' in lieu of which in classical and modern Latin orthography we would have the diphthong 'ae'. When it is not represented by the 'æ' grapheme, it is represeented by a simple 'e' grapheme.
Space to separate words (sgn - TBA: I'm currently not using this)
Full stop, written on the base line
Middle dot, written at middle heigth
It looks like a comma, written from the middle to the base line
Punctuation sign: a triangle pointing downwards
Punctuation sign for interrogative sentences. The ink is faded, but it seems to look like a tilde with one dot below only (not with two dots, as it normally is in the Beneventan script).
Punctuation sign looking like a modern colon (:)
It looks like the sign encoded as “|”, but in addition it has two dots (like a diaeresis) above

This punctuation sign is composed of three signs. The bottom sign looks like a comma, the middle one like a dot (allograph vertical1.png) or like a horizontal dash(allograph vertical2.png) and the top one like a dot. It is used starting from folio 2v, column a, line 35 and seems to be due to the second hand, that writes in black ink.
Written over another grapheme, mostly for a missing 'm'
Written over another grapheme, mostly for a missing 's' or 'm'. In 1r its shape resambles a '2' (see 2a.png), then, starting from 1v, it takes a less curved allograph (2b.png)
Written over another grapheme, mostly for a missing m'
Macron/tilde over one or more graphemes (over one 'n' means 'non')
It looks like a modern semicolon (;), written on the right of a final letter (mostly 'q;' for 'que' and 'b;' for 'bus')
A small 'u' written over a 'q'. The 'q-with-ų-above' abbreviation means 'qu' (I might just use the regular 'u': TBA)
'p' with a horizontal stroke crossing the descending trait
'p' mostly written with a tail continuing from the round trait of the 'p' on the bottom left side (but also with a separate asterisk or another mark on the same side)
'q' with a horizontal stroke crossing the descending trait
A dash with one dot above and one below, meaning 'est'
